comments.commentBody:
"I guess with their international debts denominated in the common currency the Germans feel confident they will get paid."

- and I guess (yours) is one of the big misunderstandings.
Hardly any German I ever talked to "feels confident they will get paid"!

@pieceofcake,

Then perhaps you are in truth at odds with your central bankers. For their actions would tend to indicate otherwise.

This all just looks like mercantilism without the benefit of a commodity based money. I have never understood why the country that ends up with the big stack of paper is considered the winner and the one with all the toys is considered the loser.

I guess with their international debts denominated in the common currency the Germans feel confident they will get paid.

But without excess production of real goods and services by their debtors how will that ever be possible?

This is the natural consequence of a law that was so complex, poorly thought out, and sold to the nation based on a lie.

It would be fun to watch the Democrats scurrying around for political cover, but it's just too sad.

What the GOP is not winning as a result of Ted Cruz's efforts is public approval. During the shutdown/debt ceiling debacle, support for the Republican brand dipped into the single digits. That disapproval will almost certainly be reflected in next year's election results. Meantime, Tea Party candidates did horribly in the recent off-year elections.

Nicely done, Senator Cruz.

"Ever since Senator Cruz arrived this year, the GOP looks completely different. They aren't afraid to fight, and have actually started winning on all the major issues: gun control, sequester, Syria, amnesty, and now healthcare."

What are you referring to when you say the GOP has started winning on healthcare? As I recall, Senator Cruz lost his fight against the ACA, after wasting millions in the government shutdown, and trashing the Republican's poll numbers.

What is the mechanism by which Cruz listens to the American people if he does not pay attention to the national polls?

Ever since Senator Cruz arrived this year, the GOP looks completely different. They aren't afraid to fight, and have actually started winning on all the major issues: gun control, sequester, Syria, amnesty, and now healthcare.

This shows that our system of checks and balances functions as it was intended. Government overreach can be controlled.

You're right about "technical" virginity.  The writer HAS had sex -- happily, it seems; she just hasn't experienced vaginal penetration.  And yes, there's a hoarding vibe to her focus on that, similar to her self-described approach to stuff.

It sounds as if you are a virgin only in a technical sense. You have already experienced sexuality with men; emotionally, what's the difference between what you've done and what you're saving yourself for? Your ruminations over the contents of your refrigerator may be telling you something. There's no need to continue being hung up over a technical issue; your fears of betrayal, etc., have meaning. They are indeed worth fearing, but not obsessing over at the expense of living your life. On the other hand, if you truly don't care if you ever have sex -- and you're right, we all miss out on plenty of important things in life & we can't do it all -- then what's the worry?

You're correct.  The judges involved likely know how tied their hands will be if a guilty verdict results, well before it happens.  In cases where it is likely to prevent a gross injustice, they should be prepared to return a verdict NOV of not guilty (thus overruling the jury).

The fault in this obscene miscarriage of justice lies with our elected lawmakers, not appointed Federal judges.  A judge's role is, and should be, applying the law as written, not  unilaterally deciding which laws should or should not be followed.  That said, I would have tremendous respect for a judge who chose to resign in protest, rather than impose a cruel and patently unjust mandatory sentence.

Prosecutors who withhold exculpating evidence or otherwise railroad people into prison should be made to serve the time that their victims faced. Instead, only one prosecutor in the entire country was sentenced for wrongfully convicting a man who served 25 years--and the prosecutor got 10 days.

And what's the matter with these judges? Why don't they have the courage to dismiss the cases, rather than sentence a minor offender to life without parole? They destroy people's lives, destroy entire families because--as Inspector Javert said, "The law is the law." If standing up for justice costs them their nice cushy jobs, they can always go back to practicing law.
Who do you think runs the FDA?

Dr. K,

It has been painful to watch the health insurance industry put President Obama on the run. The forces of darkness for the repeal of Obamacare seems to be working and they have set Democratic candidates up for a loss in 2014.

My brother Ron says and I agree, "I feel that a productive use of the Senate’s time as we await the outcome of ACA I.T. fixes would be to investigate the decades-long sale of substandard health care insurance to many millions of citizens with the complicity of fifty state insurance commissioners.

"This patchwork system of substandard health care regulation and guarantees of consumer protection has been at best faulty and at worst indicative of malfeasance. ...it is vital that elected leaders hold an immediate Senate investigation to determine how all these substandard obfucated policies, as evidenced by the millions of cancellations, were ever validated by the state and sold in the marketplace.

"Citizens are expecting the private health care insurance industry to operate and offer honest products, which will protect their health care needs at an affordable price. The record of the health care insurance industry is highly questionable, because of their propensity to only sell insurance to healthy people and deny claims and cancel policies at every turn. To trust the health care insurance industry to write health care policy would be as stupid as trusting food and drug producers to write policies to protect consumers of food and drugs."

I like the Buchanan angle, though ---  not only a lifetime bachelor (with BFF stowed in a White House bedroom) but the same beautiful silver hair.  AND Buchanan managed to do nothing  at all to forestall the coming nationla division and the war.  Graham seems likely to be good at that too.

Yours is the most intelligent comment. The most disgusting thing is the pretence that Graham, or for that matter any of the Republicans, gives a flip about the 'four innocent lives lost in Benghazi'. They are merely a useful stick with which to beat Obama, as much a campaign prop as a kissed baby.

It's sad enough these people died. It is worse that after their death, when they cannot fight back, they are subjected to what GB Shaw called "the only real tragedy in life ... to be used by personally minded men for purposes which you recognize to be base'.
Bingo, there it is. Keep the Benghazi issue alive so that it remains an issue if Hilary should run. This is the transparent reason for his actions.

Senator Graham must run for re-election in 2014 but first he must get past the Tea Party challenger in the Republican primary. This "hold" antic helps him build his credibility with those who might defect to vote for the TP challenger. His position is further strengthened because this "hold" seemingly challenges the Fed, a hated target of the Tea Party, and especially since the nominee was nominated by President Obama and is a woman.

South Carolina comes early in the Republican Presidential Primary cycle and could give Sen Graham an advantage in becoming the Presidential or Vice-Presidential nominee - especially since he keeps his hair neatly parted and doesn't make stupid remarks about women and reproduction.

Still, it's unlikely Sen Graham can garner the Republican Presidential nomination. The U.S. has't elected a life-long bachelor since James Buchanan. That would make Sen Graham fodder for a bored media fascinated with endlessly finding new ways to ask "what if" to compare Sen Graham to the star-crossed Buchanan presidency.

Sen Graham is also pursuing Benghazi because he expects to be re-elected to the Senate, to be part of the 2016 Presidential race, and wants to wound Secretary Clinton with the topic.

What we have in Sen Graham is yet another typical Republican - puts his personal goals ahead of even our nation's simplest needs such as staffing government mandated offices.

True enough, but regardless, business has to have a positive cash flow to stay in business, in this case to be around to pay the bills. It is just mathematics. The only alternative to commercial business is for all the taxpayers to continually fill a single pot of gold, for those needing medical attention to draw from. The question will then be, how much of the burden each person bears to fill it. And surely, those "Millionaires & Billionaires" will be villified, just as sure as the sun rises each day.

The Democrats have no one to blame but themselves. Progressive-leaners warned this configuration -- individual mandate combined with no public option -- is nothing but corporate welfare for the insurance companies. What could be better for a corporate CEO than the gov't forcing, under threat of law, every single American to purchase your product? The Democrats were fairly warned in early 2010 that the health insurance CEO's would hike the rates, then be rubbing their greedy hands together awaiting their force-fed money to roll into their coffers.

Surprise, surprise, guess what happened?

The Democrats made their bed, now, unfortunately for them, they must sleep in it.

In order to "be more G.W. Bush than G.W. Bush was" Mr. Obama would have to get John Kerry to declare that Mongolia was responsible for messing up the HealthCare.gov site and then send the marines to Ulan Bator to overthrow the government and expropriate the nation's supply of yak wool in the interests of defending our cherished freedoms.

The USA is exceptional all right.
Just not in the way its cheerleaders mean.

Judge Spencer is to be applauded for his public assertions of the injustice on display here.  But it is far worse than "just silly" (I know he didn't intend to minimize the injustice by characterizing it that way, but it gives a good entre): it is even far worse than injustice, travesty, tragedy.  It is morally repugnant.  Lives and families torn asunder by fearful, over-moralizing and arbitrary (and yes, at the very least in effect, racist) "leaders." I defy any exponents of "American exceptionalism" to reassert their claims in the face of this disgusting debacle.  The US is not the land of the free, it is the land of repression.

Wonderful idea by the Times and wonderful contributions from its readers. Fifty years later,  I am still appalled by our government sending men and women to die for no reason in Vietnam and by many of our citizens treating the innocent soldiers as war criminals.

Your are indeed a lucky one, honest for at least your own self, know better then most doctors or others that are pure simple quacks in for the buck with the pharmaceutical and medical establishment. Their guardian angles of profits above all else. These days doctors practice medicine virtue of pill, powders,  prescription drugs . That on the whole are far more abused with impunity then illicit drugs. I personally know University hospital that is over 100 years old. The ICU and CCU units have policies that patients should not be allowed  to wash themselves or take showers in bath rooms attached to their rooms.  temps cannot be controlled. The organization keep them cold ( about 65 F) to avoid growth of bacteria , just as prisons and jail. No rinse chemical wash at $45 is standard.  One PA  makes rounds to check on some 50 Plus  Cardiac patients, The surgeons, and cardiologists  never visit their patients. Most of the residents live some miles  away and even critical situation practice medicine over the telephone in their communications with nurses, most of who are from foreign countries and never supported by the  doctors . But rather used abused and exploited.   Open heart surgery patients after total of less then ten days are shuttled into so called skilled care nursing under the tutelage of the same CEO President . There ONE doctor  geriatrics specialist, one RN and a nurse practitioner , who thinks she is an MD. Over some foreign LPNs who follow the same pill regime as ICU

I think my prof said "...all medications are poisons..." Of course that was long ago. I agree in re inflammation and statins but CoQ10 is also necessary as a replacement for its side effects, muscle pain, etc.

I think, dear colleague that you’re «accusing». You don’t seem ready to look at the extraordinary benefits of drugs like statins which have contributed significantly to the decrease in cardio-vascular morbidity and mortality in the last 2 decades worldwide. Why?
José Raymond Herrera MA, MD, FACE.

This is what happens when a bunch of lawyers who have no idea about health and disease invent a 2000 page document called  Affordable Care Act. This is somewhat akin to a bunch of doctors coming up with ideas to reform the constitution. I did vote for Obama,  for I am not a single issue voter.

well the very simple answer here is that your insurance company should be made to include pregnancy coverage at the same cost.to you   Since YOU would presumably not be using it and some others, presumably with the same plan might be (but probably more no's than yeses here), the cost would be minimal at best to the insurance company. In fact they would probably still make money.  This is not about the law as much as it is about what the insurance companies are trying to get away with.

The Democrats are really exposed on this one. They pressed for this entire plan, sold Congress on it (but only a small plurality of the American people), defended it against constitutional challenge because John Roberts changed his mind, and, yet, never thought through the details that a behemoth project like this entails. We were told that Americans who liked their existing plans could keep them. Is it possible, Homer, that your premiums are going to go up - dramatically and for inferior coverage - because we are now going to dole out care to a lot of people who, for whatever reason, are just not going to pay for their share of it?

Was it really all going to be as easy, cheap, and quick as Obama promised?

Maybe not.
You can thank Medicare for that, as it sets a floor under what the medical establishment is allowed to charge ALL Americans. There is no free market.

All of this should be a moot point! The REAL issue isn't access to health insurance, rather it's that health care in the United States is too damn expensive and delivers sub-standard results, no matter how you choose to look at it.

Even the best statisticians would have a difficult time justifying the prices charged by the medical establishment (both doctors and hospitals).

I wish they'd focus on the COST of health care rather than all of this insurance fluff. $10k+/year for insurance, and that's before I even set foot in a single dr's office.

But who is say that a policy is sub-standard?  What about a policy that doesn't cover drug rehab or maternity expenses?  That policy would be sub-standard under ACA but I don't need either of these provisions.  So I wouldn't consider an insurance policy that exempted these services as sub-standard.
You can thank Medicare for that, as it sets a floor under what the medical establishment is allowed to charge ALL Americans. There is no free market.

Public option, single payer, is the solution. Everything else will be perpetuating this "crisis," the "glitches," etc. BTW where were the democrats when the public option was put off the negotiating table? That was the moment for the outcry.

Not quite. It's the government that needs an overhaul. Its citizens merely need to be respected.

M.Z., you are most likely yet another one of those folks not being dropped by your insurer, and forced into a more expensive policy with higher deductibles.

Everyone talks about how many tens of thousands of medicare enrollments have been done. Question is how many be totally processed?

In one method of enrollment, the application has to go from the state to the feds and back again. The feds haven't been sending a lot of the applications back to the states. That means the people who signed up aren't actually enrolled yet and they might not even know it until they walk into the doctor's office and get told the insurance isn't there.

Democrats are being alarmists instead of standing with President Obama and getting the website fixed.  I do not appreciate Joe Manchin or any other Democrat who is just trying to hurt the law to save themselves any grief.  What I want is a united Democratic Party all on the same page wanting to get the web site working and to stop all this drama.  Republicans hate the Affordable Care Act and they are not trying in any way to cover people with health insurance. That is what Democrats are doing and it is a great thing and a wonderful thing and I support the ACA 100 percent and I really do  not understand the hate from republicans for better health care coverage other than that they believe anything barfed from fox lies.

Probably because you are totally incorrect.  It is the ACA aka Obamacare that mandated that any change to an existing plan automatically erases its grandfathered status.  So as soon as any carrier's plan has to adjust to any ACA mandate, that's the end of it.  I understand your well-meaning progressive ideology.  But it's time to wake up and smell the coffee.  Obamacare is hurting as many people as it is helping.
Pipe dream!  With this Obama disaster now evolving into a down right glaring catastrophic political scar, fortunately, they'll never be able pass another health care policy in our lifetimes.

I think this is an insurance company issue. They need to get in touch with
a good agent.
